content: pistachio ice cream cowl the pistachio ice cream cowl feels like a warm hug on a chilly day the faux rib adds a lot of visual interest to the design as well as giving it such a squishy scrumptious texture i made my small sample in a color block design and my large sample in a single color but try experimenting with any color design you like it s very easy to adjust to your liking made in bulky yarn this is a quick project perfect for last minute gifts or a treat for yourself about this pattern this cowl is worked from side to side seamed with a slip_stitch at the edges you can easily adjust this to your preferred width and length although there are only two sizes in the pattern there are two options one for a cowl that sits around your neck s and one for a cowl that wraps around twice l here are how the sizes will be displayed…s l if there is only one number follow those instructions for both sizes my green/white sample is in size s my light green sample was made in size l you can do it in solids stripes or color blocks this is an intermediate level pattern as you need to know fpdc and basic slip_stitch seaming 1 gauge 9 stitches/5 row in the ribbed repeat in the pattern 4 by 4 materials ● bulky weight yarn* in however many colors you wish or one if you are doing a single color ● *notes for my s sample i used lambs pride in the color way pistachio and drops snow which is categorized as a super bulky weight but it was the same thickness as my other yarn in the color way marshmallow ● for my l sample i used drops alpaca silk held double in the colorway pistachio ● 7mm hook ● yarn needle to weave in ends ● scissors abbreviations* us terms but here is a link to convert them to uk terms r row repeat s repeat s st s stitch es double_crochet double_crochet stitch chain chain stitch fpdc front post double_crochet stitch rs right side ws wrong side *note abbreviations mean the same thing whether capitalized or not start crocheting here r1 rs ● make a slip knot and slip it on your hook chain 20 and double_crochet into the back loop of the second chain from your hook double_crochet all the way across the chain working into the back loops chain 1* turn your work *note chain 1 doesn t count as a stitch here and throughout the pattern r2 ws ● double_crochet into the first st then fpdc into every st until you get to the last st
